column1: 0-1 Knapsack: max weight, items with values and weights, maximize value
column2:
DP Best[i][w]
O(n W)

column1: Array: Convert array into Zig-Zag fashion: distinct element or not cases
column2:
distinct O(n)|O(1) aux bubble sort-like swap
not distinct QuickSelect to find median, partition O(n)

column1: Array: find subarray with maximum sum
column2: one pass, at each position either extend or start new subarray O(n)|O(1)

column1: Array: find the majority element
column2: Boyer-Moore voting algorithm O(n)

column1: Array: find the median of non-sorted array
column2: QuickSelect O(n)

column1: Array: Longest Increasing Subsequence
column2:
DP O(n^2).

also possible in O(n log n)
with active lists and binary search

column1: Array: Next Greater element in an array
column2:
using a stack
O(n)/O(n)

column1: Array: Smallest subarray with sum greater than a given value
column2:
Sliding window: keep adding array elements while current sum is smaller than x
If current sum becomes greater than x, update min length, remove starting elements

column1: Array: Stock Buy Sell to Maximize Profit (buy & sell multiple times)
column2:
1. Find the local minima and store it as starting index. If not exists, return.
2. Find the local maxima. and store it as ending index. If we reach the end, set the end as ending index.
3. Update the solution (Increment count of buy sell pairs)
4. Repeat the above steps if end is not reached.

column1:
combination sum: Given a set of candidate numbers (C) (without duplicates) and a target number (T), find all unique combinations in C where the candidate numbers sums to T.,
same number can be repeated
column2: backtracking (or DP)

column1: Container With Most Water
column2:
two pointers, from start and end,
reduce width and stop only when height increases,

O(n)|O(1)

column1: Graph: Bridges in a Graph
column2: Naive: remove edge, see if graph is still connected: O(E (V + E)). Better algorithm based on DFS O(V + E) exists.

column1: Graph: Minimum Spanning tree Kruskal: algorithm and complexity
column2:
sort edges by weight,
(take min edge, check if it introduces a cycle in the partial tree, discard or add).
Cycle detection with union-find

O(E log E)

column1: Graph: Minimum Spanning tree Prim: algorithm and complexity
column2:
greedy vertices: add new vertex of minimum distance to partial tree.
O(V^2),
can be reduced with binary heap.

column1: Graph: Topological sort of DAG (2)
column2:
1. DFS: prepend to list after calling DFS on adjacent vertices (so they are on the stack below). O(V + E).
2. BFS-style algorithm: find vertices of in-degree 0, process, remove edges to other vertices, repeat

column1: LinkedList: insertion in linked list tip
column2: use dummy first node

column1: Longest Palindromic Substring
column2:
for each position, find longest even and odd length substring with this center O(n^2)|O(1)
DP bottom-up with length-0 length-1 -2 ... substrings O(n^2)|O(1)

O(n) difficult Manacher.

column1: Max number of intersecting intervals
column2: sort events: enter and exist of intervals. O(n log n)|O(n) aux

column1: Minimum difference partition
column2:
DP CanMakeSum[i][T],
T <= S/2
O(n S)

column1: String: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters
column2: Window. left and right pointers, hash set for characters in the substring, move either left or right O(n)|O(n) // traverse left to right, maintaining longest valid substring ending at this position, use map<char,position> to know where current character appeared last O(n)|O(n)

column1: String: substring search
column2:
naive O(n*m)

robin-karp rolling hash O(n + m)

advanced O(n)

column1: Subset sum: a subset of array sums to T
column2:
DP CanMakeSum[i][T]
O(n S)

column1: Tree: Check if a binary tree is subtree of another binary tree
column2:
Naive O(n^2),

O(n): inorder and preorder of subtree must be substrings of big tree

column1: Tree: Maximum path sum in a binary tree

recursive, only left, only right, both
